name: Phenelzine (Nardil)
summary: Phenelzine, sold under the brand name Nardil, is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) used primarily for the treatment of major depressive disorder, especially atypical depression, and certain anxiety disorders.
description: Phenelzine is a non-selective, irreversible monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) that increases levels of serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine in the brain by blocking their breakdown. It is typically reserved for patients who have not responded to other antidepressants due to its dietary restrictions and drug interaction risks. Phenelzine is effective in treating atypical depression, panic disorder, and social anxiety disorder.

contraindications: Concomitant use with SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, buspirone, meperidine, or sympathomimetics

items: Treatment of major depressive disorder, particularly atypical depression

sections.text: Phenelzine irreversibly inhibits both MAO-A and MAO-B enzymes, preventing the breakdown of monoamines (serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine) and increasing their availability in the synaptic cleft.

adult.Depression/anxiety: Initial: 15 mg orally three times daily; may be increased to a maximum of 90 mg/day in divided doses.

sections.geriatric: Lower starting doses recommended; monitor closely for orthostatic hypotension and drug interactions.

sections.text: Antidepressant effects may be seen within 2â€“4 weeks; full effects may take longer.

sections.black_box: Increased risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults.
other: Requires strict dietary restrictions to avoid tyramine-containing foods
Long washout period required when switching to/from other serotonergic agents
May cause hypertensive crisis if dietary/drug restrictions are not followed

items.action: Avoid aged cheeses, cured meats, fermented products

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; data in pregnancy are limited.
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in breast milk; caution advised.

sections.text: Gradual taper recommended to avoid withdrawal symptoms such as agitation, anxiety, and insomnia.
